overview_summary: All five profiled neighbors have an undetermined stance on the development, as none have any documented public support or opposition. Most appear to have low community influence, with only one (a 99-year-old lifelong resident active in 4-H) having moderate local involvement. No high-ranking officials or outspoken activists were identified among these landowners.

neighbors.name: Robert & Susan Shotto
neighbors.claims: Robert and Susan Shotto owned a one-acre residential property on Summit Point Road in Jefferson County for five years before selling it in August 2024 [Homes.com](https://www.homes.com/property/7963-summit-point-rd-charles-town-wv/mvf5y4r57ybnb/#!/history)[Homes.com](https://www.homes.com/property/7963-summit-point-rd-charles-town-wv/mvf5y4r57ybnb/#!/history). No evidence could be found of the Shottos participating in local meetings or taking public positions on development issues.

approach_recommendations.engage: Given they have sold their property and left the area, direct engagement is likely unnecessary beyond general community outreach.

neighbors.name: William R. & Janice E. Curtis
neighbors.claims: William and Janice Curtis are listed as owners of a parcel in Jefferson County, West Virginia (near Summit Point), but they maintain a very low public profile (no mention in news archives or civic records). There are no public statements or documented civic roles for the Curtis family in local affairs.

approach_recommendations.engage: Approach the Curtises through a personal, neighborly conversation to hear any concerns. Emphasize respect for their property and address any questions they have about the project.

neighbors.name: Vera H. Reid
neighbors.claims: Vera H. Reid was a lifelong Jefferson County resident who passed away in August 2024 at the age of 99 [Melvin Strider Funeral Home](https://www.mtstrider.com/obituary/vera-hammersla-reid). She was a longtime 4-H club leader and even served on the Jefferson County 4-H Foundation’s Board of Directors, reflecting her deep roots and community involvement [Melvin Strider Funeral Home](https://www.mtstrider.com/obituary/vera-hammersla-reid).

approach_recommendations.engage: Coordinate with Ms. Reid’s family or estate representatives, honoring her family’s legacy in the community and showing respect for the longstanding ties of her property.

neighbors.name: Bonnie L. McDonald & Carroll E. Harder
neighbors.claims: Bonnie McDonald and Carroll Harder jointly own a residential lot in Jefferson County (identified in county records as parcel 19-02-11A-68). They have not been publicly involved in county committees or land use debates, according to available records. No press or official reports mention either McDonald or Harder taking positions on local development.

approach_recommendations.engage: Engage this household through informal, friendly outreach within their neighborhood. Emphasize maintaining the peace and privacy of their wooded community when discussing project plans.

neighbors.name: Stephen T. & Judith R. Smoot
neighbors.claims: Stephen and Judith Smoot own property in Jefferson County (in the same subdivision as the Harder/McDonald parcel). They do not appear in any local news reports or civic records, indicating they have kept to themselves regarding county issues. There is no public record of the Smoots voicing opinions on development or energy projects in the community.

approach_recommendations.engage: Approach the Smoots as private homeowners through direct, respectful communication. Listening to any concerns they have in a one-on-one setting and reassuring them about property and community impacts will help build trust.
